messageBody:
Hill,

This is similar to work we are doing to support more time-efficient testing.
We don't have a general, pluggable solution. One of the problems is that
each of the runners out there (Eclipse, IntelliJ, Ant, Maven) has their own
mechanism to run tests and report results. They don't generally go through
JUnitCore, so we don't have a hook to add our own logging.

You'll have to hack something up if you want it now. Your custom runner idea
would work but might be fragile. Another possibility is to put together
minimal plug-ins for Eclipse and IntelliJ (Eclipse, anyway, offers an
extension point for tracking test runs) and a task for your build system to
deposit reports in some central location. This would be more work than the
runner, but would leave you free to use custom runners for other purposes.

The bigger issue is how to offer a test runner API that all the UIs would be
satisfied using and would offer universal extension points. I'm tempted to
call a workshop for all the potential consumers of such an interface and see
how much we could get done in a week.

Regards,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

_____

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
uly562000
Sent: Wednesday, October 08, 2008 9:22 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Adding a listener without using core?



Context: I am writing code that monitors the frequency, timing, and
results of tests, and the code needs must run from eclipse, intellij,
etc, relatively invisibly to the user.

As far as I can tell, the only way to add a listener is to do it
through the JUnitCore class. Unfortunately, I can't use the standard
formula of running from main().

Is there a way to add a listener from elsewhere in the dynamic object
tree?

I have a deliciously crude hack: Use RunsWith and a custom runner,
then change the invokeMethod statement so that I can gather the info I
need. It would be so much nicer if I could just add a listener, tho,
because my hack would require me to extract all the info, which in
fact a listener already gets all nicely packaged.

Ideas?
Hill
